Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem is that windows is searching for a DIFFERENT filename, prepending :7771 to it!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: gotta love all these deviations from sanity to lock people into an obsolete system

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @TonyL pushed fix so it will work for non-KMD coins too

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also do you know how to add a new coin to coins file? it is good to know how to do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and now we just need a cross platform installer that can launch ./nspv and open the 127.0.0.1:port page

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am working with satinder to get the html wallet actually working, but as far as installer goes as long as the html files are in html directory where the ./nspv is when launched, it will work

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and my analysis is that the localhost html will be pretty much as secure as cli, the only exception is if your browser has some sort of localhost intercept exploit

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is totally static .html

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no javascript

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all dynamically generated from inside nspv

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we can get what looks like a webwallet, with electrum server speed, nearly fullnode cli security

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is fully decentralized

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c 
how is txproof used?
```bash
curl --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "txproof", "params": ["e07709088fa2690fdc71b43b5d7760689e42ca90f7dfb74b18bf47a1ad94c855",0,1453881 ] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:$port/
```
```json
{
  "txid": "e07709088fa2690fdc71b43b5d7760689e42ca90f7dfb74b18bf47a1ad94c855",
  "height": 1453881,
  "txlen": 244,
  "txprooflen": 1655,
  "lastpeer": "nodeid.1"
}
```

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Going to have to totally start again and add more code to daemon to make the validation work. Simply cannot make it sync backwards won't fetch the headers, I spent 2 entire days messing with it and got not very far. Best thing to do will be to fetch all of the headers from say 3     random nodes, all in one call, because getinfo spam just breaks everything.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: What if 1 or 2 nodes disagree on headers, or all 3 are malicious? Electrum is dealing with problems just like this, so I think it's important to design for that threat scenario

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I tried to make it fetch blocks randomly from all nodes, but it just wont handle the load

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Either there is some fatal flaw in how it all works, or I did something wrong, but it doesnt seem to me you can quickly request blocks from some X% of nodes

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
As things are that is. I think an extra call needs to be made that can fetch a range of headers from 1 node. 
Then the client can request the range from multiple nodes, then compare them to make sure they match. We only need to find 1 notarization that all nodes agree on I think, but that doesnt mean a node and just make fake block headers, after this notarization

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: So you need to have data from many nodes ..

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Even then, many nodes could be malicious.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
The other way to do it, is just make people wait ðŸ¤£  
You just cant make any tx or do anything until it has enough received blocks.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: We want to make the average attack scenario more costly for the attacker while not reducing user-visible features, if possible

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r choose 10 nodes randomly each startup, and I would say that is pretty good. If it isn't, you are being Sybil-attacked and probably have worse problems

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: James explained that you only need 1 good server to prove the other 9 wrong

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yes, but you need allthe data from ALL the nodes to do that

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: so you ned a full node basically

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that means only 10% of network needs to be good servers, on average, to protect against 90% evil servers

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: When it starts up, there is onyl 1 node

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: james's

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: then his node sends you the rest

Content: what about the concept of a DNS seed?

Content: at start up I cant randomly choose a few nodes because they are not there

Content: a hostname which returns many IPs, trusted seed nodes
